text: I have seen an end of all perfection: but thy commandment is exceeding broad.
text_kjv: I have seen an end of all perfection: but thy commandment is exceeding broad.
text_niv: To all perfection I see a limit;but your commands are boundless.
text_esv: I have seen a limit to all perfection, but your commandment is exceedingly broad.
text_nlt: Even perfection has its limits,but your commands have no limit.
text_msg: I see the limits to everything human,but the horizons can't contain your commands!
text_nasb: I have seen a limit to all perfection; Your commandment is exceedingly broad. Mem.
context: Psalm 119, the longest chapter in the Bible, is an acrostic poem praising God's law (Torah). Each of its 176 verses emphasizes the beauty, power, and importance of God's word through various synonyms – law, statutes, precepts, commands, judgments, word, testimonies, and ways. Understanding the historical context requires recognizing the high value placed on Torah in ancient Israelite society. The Torah wasn't just a set of rules; it was seen as God's self-revelation, a guide for righteous living, and the foundation of their covenant relationship with Him. The author, traditionally attributed to David, though some scholars suggest a later date, likely composed this psalm during a time of personal or national hardship. The emphasis on God's word as a source of comfort, guidance, and hope suggests a period where the author felt overwhelmed by the world's imperfections and the limitations of human endeavors. The reference to "perfection" likely refers to the various standards and ideals pursued by humans in the ancient world, such as physical beauty, wealth, power, or philosophical wisdom. The psalm emphasizes that these perceived perfections are finite and ultimately unsatisfying. The word "commandment" (or "command") connects to the broader Hebrew understanding of covenant. It's not just an order, but a pathway to relational wholeness with God. The word 'broad' in this context signifies extensiveness, completeness, and inexhaustibility, contrasting sharply with the limited scope of earthly perfections.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 119:96 declares the inadequacy of all earthly ideals compared to the boundless nature of God's law. The psalmist recognizes that every human pursuit of perfection eventually reaches its limit. Wealth can be lost, beauty fades, power corrupts, and even human wisdom has its boundaries. These "perfections" are finite and transient, offering only temporary satisfaction. In contrast, God's commandment (His word, His instruction, His covenant) is exceedingly broad. This breadth speaks to several key theological truths. First, it highlights the comprehensiveness of God's law. It addresses every aspect of human life, offering guidance for relationships, morality, worship, and personal conduct. Second, it underscores the depth of God's law. It isn't merely a set of external rules, but a reflection of God's character and a pathway to knowing Him intimately. Studying and obeying God's word leads to a deeper understanding of His love, justice, and mercy. Third, it reveals the endless application of God's law. It is relevant for all people, in all places, and at all times. Its principles are timeless and universal, providing a foundation for a life of righteousness and purpose. The contrast between the limited nature of earthly perfections and the boundless scope of God's commandment reveals the ultimate source of true and lasting fulfillment. It points us away from the fleeting pleasures of the world and towards the enduring treasure of God's word.
application: In our modern world, Psalm 119:96 holds profound practical implications. We are constantly bombarded with messages promising happiness and fulfillment through various means: wealth, success, beauty, relationships, and even ideologies. We are told that achieving a certain body image, reaching a specific career milestone, or accumulating a certain amount of wealth will finally bring us contentment. However, like the psalmist, we eventually discover that these "perfections" are fleeting and ultimately unsatisfying. They have limits, they can be taken away, and they often leave us feeling empty and unfulfilled. This verse challenges us to re-evaluate our priorities and to shift our focus from the pursuit of earthly perfections to the pursuit of God's will as revealed in His word. It encourages us to spend less time chasing after fleeting pleasures and more time studying and meditating on scripture. How can we apply this practically? Start by setting aside dedicated time each day to read and reflect on God's word. Don't just read passively; actively engage with the text, asking questions, seeking understanding, and applying the principles to your own life. Join a Bible study group to learn from others and to hold yourself accountable. Memorize key verses to carry with you throughout the day, allowing them to guide your thoughts and actions. Pray for understanding and wisdom as you study God's word. Furthermore, this verse calls us to be discerning consumers of information and cultural trends. We should critically evaluate the messages we receive from the world, comparing them to the truth of God's word. When faced with difficult decisions, we should turn to scripture for guidance and direction. By anchoring our lives in the boundless and unchanging truth of God's word, we can find lasting fulfillment and purpose that transcends the fleeting pleasures of this world.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often chase after fleeting and imperfect things. I am drawn to the promises of the world, believing that wealth, success, or beauty will bring me happiness. Forgive me for placing my trust in things that ultimately fail to satisfy. Help me to see the limitations of earthly perfections and to turn my heart towards your boundless and enduring word. Grant me a hunger for your truth and the wisdom to understand it. May your commandments guide my steps and lead me to a life of righteousness and purpose. Thank you for the gift of your word, which is a lamp to my feet and a light to my path. In Jesus’ name, Amen.

faqs.answer: What does it mean that God's commandment is "exceedingly broad"? It means that God's word covers every aspect of life. It is not narrow or limited, but encompasses all of our thoughts, actions, and relationships, providing guidance for every situation we face.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse

faqs.answer: How does this verse relate to the concept of grace? While the law reveals God's standard, grace provides the means to fulfill it. Christ fulfilled the law perfectly on our behalf, offering forgiveness and enabling us to live righteously through the power of the Holy Spirit.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: Can we truly understand the full breadth of God's commandment? No, we will never fully grasp its infinite depth, but that shouldn’t stop us from continually seeking to know God and His ways better. It is a lifelong pursuit of understanding and obedience.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: How does this verse challenge the idea of relativism? Relativism says truth is subjective and changes. Psalm 119:96, contrasts with this, asserting that God’s law is objective and unchanging, surpassing all human opinions and preferences.
faqs.question: Q4

faqs.answer: Is the pursuit of excellence wrong, given this verse? No, pursuing excellence is not inherently wrong. However, if we look to excellence as our ultimate source of fulfillment, then it will ultimately fall short and we will be dissapointed.
faqs.question: Q5
